Science has a replication problem. Should funding be shifted to address this?

"you could put your money into 100 psychology experiments. At the end of the day, you’d have produced a large stack of papers, some of which might be important, and some of which might even be true."

Whereas funding 100 replication experiments would "impact tens of thousands of subsequent papers by creating momentum for improved standards in the field."

title: Russian Flights being informed about Canada's Airspace Ban

last_post.content:
@scott_bot while I am at it here is a memorable example of NOTAMs in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_KvP8XR30w

This is when lots of countries closed their airspaces to Russian aircraft abruptly following the invasion of Ukraine. Naturally, some Russian aircraft were _in the air_ at that time! The NOTAM system is how you push out breaking changes affecting airspace, so that's how they heard. The video is ATC communicating with Russian pilots. The professionalism and mutual helpfulness in the conversation both inspires me and breaks my heart.

title: A Litany for Survival by Audre Lorde | Poetry Foundation

last_post.content:
Morning #poetry

and when we speak we are afraid
our words will not be heard
nor welcomed
but when we are silent
we are still afraid

So it is better to speak
remembering
we were never meant to survive.

Audre Lorde, "A Litany for Survival"

#neuroscience #preprint

A new study looking into somatostatin-expressing neurons in the mouse VTA has emerged from our lab, available as a preprint on bioRxiv:
https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.01.06.522982

The study - led by my great colleagues Elina Nagaeva and Annika Schäfer - is straight continuation on Elina's eralier work published in @eLife in 2020 where molecular and electrophysiological properties of somatostatin-expressing cells of mouse VTA were charaterized (available here https://doi.org/10.7554/eLife.59328).

In the current preprint we went on to try to see what those neurons do.

title: A Profession, If You Can Keep It

last_post.content:
If you want to understand the incredible disjuncture between the old guard of historians and those on the front lines seriously seeking to stop the collapse of the profession, read this account of outgoing AHA president James Sweet's speech https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/08/arts/american-historical-association-james-sweet.html

and then @erin_bartram's talk
https://contingentmagazine.org/2023/01/07/a-profession-if-you-can-keep-it/

Many (not all) tenured senior profs are apparently content to keep debating methodology while the profession burns. It isn't just professionally irresponsible; it's unethical. The luxury of being able to have those debates is enabled by inequitable labor conditions and a failure to take responsibility for training grad students for nonexistent jobs.

#histodons #AHA23

title: Long COVID - Household Pulse Survey - COVID-19

last_post.content:
Looking through the HPS long COVID questions and the numbers are pretty crazy.

Over 50% of US adults have had COVID

Of those, 28% have had issues with long COVID, and 11% still with issues.

Of that 11%, 80% report activity limitations, a quarter with severe limitations.

1.5% of all US adults have significant activity limitation because of long COVID. That’s about 4m people.

About half of them, 2m are newly disabled.

https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/pulse/long-covid.htm

@b0rk another thing worth mentioning is why python has math.fsum, because merely summing floating point numbers is filled with treachery

on "adding very small numbers to large numbers results in no change", well (x+x) == x is true for four floats. sometimes six.

https://twitter.com/lunasorcery/status/1113816153888104449

and there's a recurrence relation—wherein using small sized floats will find the right answer, and using larger sized floats will give you the wrong answer https://etna.math.kent.edu/vol.52.2020/pp358-369.dir/pp358-369.pdf

title: The Ethics of Artificial Intelligence-Generated Art

last_post.content:
Every wild swinging hot take on the "AI" art and GPT situation goes fucking everywhere, while the few nuanced takes I've seen struggle to make it around.

This shit's neither harmless nor inevitable, AND doesn't have to be made in the harmful ways corporations will tend to making them. Algorithmic applications are primarily created from within and in service of hegemonic, carceral, capitalist profit motives, meaning they act as force multipliers/accelerants on the worst depredations of said. That goes for art and language as much as it goes for housing and policing.

Neither tech nor play are neutral categories and these tools COULD be used to help a lot of people. But until we get the capitalist shit off of them and place meaningful regulation—that is regs specifically designed to safeguard the most marginalized and vulnerable— around the frames they're going to keep doing a lot of harm, too.

LLM's are trained on data that is both unethically sourced AND prejudicially biased in its content and they operate by means of structures that require vast amounts of natural resources. But they COULD and SHOULD be made differently

"AI" art tools can &do help people who either never could or can't any longer do art in more traditional modes create things they feel meaningfully close to. But they're also being trained on pieces by living artists scraped without their knowledge, let alone their consent or credit

I'll say it again (said it before here https://sinews.siam.org/Details-Page/the-ethics-of-artificial-intelligence-generated-art): The public domain exists, and it would have been a truly trivial matter for the people who created "AI" art tools to train them and update them on public domain works— they update literally every year. But that's not what we have, here.

GPT checkers are apparently already being deployed to try to catch GPT cheaters, but, again (https://twitter.com/Wolven/status/1599987850405371904): Why be in an adversarial stance with your students when you could use the thing to actually, y'know, teach them how to be critical of the thing? Additionally the GPT Chat checkers seem have problems with original text written by neurodivergent individuals (https://kolektiva.social/@FractalEcho/109480097279253524) and other text in general (https://www.aiweirdness.com/writing-like-a-robot/), so like many automated plagiarism checkers and online proctoring softwares their deployment directly endangers disabled and otherwise marginalized students in our classes.

Uncritical use of either GPT or "AI" art tools, or their current proposed remedies, does real harm, because the tools are built out of and play into extant harmful structures of exploitation and marginalization. But we these things can be engaged and built drastically differently.

But in order to get the regulations and strictures in place to ensure that they ARE built differently, we have to be fully honest and nuanced about what these "AI" systems are and what they do, and then we have to push very hard AGAINST the horrible shit they're built in and of.

title: America’s Biggest Museums Fail to Return Native American Human Remains

last_post.content: "At least half of the remains of more than 210,000 Native Americans have yet to be returned. Tribes have struggled to reclaim them in part because of a lack of federal funding for repatriation and because institutions face little to no consequences for violating the law or dragging their feet." Today my colleagues launched The #Repatriation Project, highlighting the incredible number of institutions who've failed to return human remains to Native American tribes: https://www.propublica.org/article/repatriation-nagpra-museums-human-remains

Wir werden den Prozess der Fermentation in verschiedenen Stadien erforschen, indem mit verschiedenen Sensoren (analog, digital, biologisch) gearbeitet wird, und wir werden gemeinsam versuchen, sensorische Daten in einer offenen, öffentlichen Datenbank (Wikidata) zu strukturieren.

"The exposed data contained the location and names of 5,770 suspects, mostly located in California. In some instances, the data included their height, weight, and eye color and indicated whether they were experiencing homelessness. For more than 1,000 of these suspects, SweepWizard also exposed their Social Security numbers. According to the data, several of these suspects were juveniles at the time of the sweeps. Arrest records and press releases confirm that several people whose names appeared in the leaked data were arrested after the raid."

{progressr} 0.13.0 on CRAN.

Setting

options(cli.progress_handlers="progressr")

makes all {cli} progress updates to be handled by {progressr}.

This is a pretty neat {cli} feature, because it allows us to use any combination of {progressr} handlers to report on progress, e.g. beepr (audio), txtprogressbar (terminal), and rstudio (RStudio's progress bar).

title: Does Your Local Museum or University Still Have Native American Remains?

last_post.content:
Does Your Local Museum or University Still Have Native American Remains?
---
In 1990, Congress passed the Native American Graves Protection & #Repatriation Act (NAGPRA), which set up a process for tribes to request the return of remains.

33 years later, at least half of the remains of more than 210,000 #NativeAmericans have yet to be returned.

Use this tool to see which #museums, #colleges & govt. agencies still have them:

https://projects.propublica.org/repatriation-nagpra-database/?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post

2. Always start a bar chart's Y axis at 0. The most common reason for violating this is to highlight differences that would otherwise be imperceptible, but that usually means another type of chart would be more appropriate.
